Next, we check the asymptotic normality (22).
performed goodness-of-fit tests on 1000 samples of
under the null hypothesis that they follow a multivariate
normal distribution. The Anderson–Darling test in the
package of R yielded a p-value of 0.9349, and
the Cram´er–von Mises test in the same package yielded
a p-value of 0.9434. The null hypothesis was accepted
with a very high p-value for both tests.
Finally, we check how the sample covariance ma-
evolves with the number of steps.

Note that the values of the
cate the ultimate limits of estimation precision displayed
in Fig. 1. In each case, the solid curve approaches the
dashed line as the number of steps increases. This means
that if the number of steps is large enough, we can es-
ously with the best accuracy theoretically possible.
It is noteworthy that, as can be seen from Figs. 5a
and 5b, the convergence becomes much slower as
closer to zero. We also find from the heatmaps in Fig. 6
